title: Woolworths reintroduces paper bags in a bid to drive down plastic use
text:
Woolworths has turned back the clock decades by offering brown paper shopping bags at its supermarkets.

The bags were spotted at a shop in Cairns this week being sold for 20c each - more expensive than its reusable plastic bags.

Woolworths has turned back the clock several decades by offering brown paper shopping bags at its supermarkets

After the photo was posted to Facebook on Thursday, other shoppers reported seeing similar bags on sale at Coles.

However, some shoppers said the paper bags were not practical as they had no handles, and were difficult to stack and carry.

They also could only fit a few grocery items and were cold goods could degrade the paper through condensation.

Paper bags were commonplace in Australian supermarkets until the late 1980s when they were gradually phased out for plastic bags.

There had been an international swing back toward paper because it is biodegradable.

The bags were brought in as an alternative after the free lightweight plastic ones were banned from supermarkets over environmental fears last year

The bags were brought in as an alternative after the free lightweight plastic ones were banned from supermarkets over environmental fears last year.

Supermarkets instead sell tougher, reusable plastic bags for 15c each and encourage customers to bring them back next time.

Coles and Woolworths have made a large windfall from selling reusable bags since implementing the ban.
description: Paper bags were spotted at a shop in Cairns this week for perhaps the first time since they were ditched for plastic ones half a century ago - but unlike back then they cost you 20c each,
authors: Nic White For Daily Mail Australia
